initial_story:
The Eurovision Song Contest is just around the corner and this year, it's taking place in Malmo, Sweden.

You can find out all about the event right here.

The UK's entry for 2024 is Olly Alexander who'll be performing his song, Dizzy.

But how's he feeling ahead of the big night, where he'll perform in front of 200 million people!

De-Graft sat down with him to find out all about his preparation for the competition.

The Eurovision Song contest Grand Final will be shown on BBC One and iPlayer on Saturday 11 May.
stories: De-Graft: Olly, congratulations on being selected to represent the UK at Eurovision! How does it feel to be one step closer to winning the competition?

Olly: Ah, thank you so much De-Graft! I'm completely overwhelmed with excitement and gratitude. To be honest, I'm still trying to process the fact that I'll be taking part in the biggest music competition in Europe. It's a dream come true!

De-Graft: Ahahaha, I knew you'd be thrilled! I'm beyond proud of you, Olly. You've worked so hard for this and you truly deserve it. What's your plan for the competition? Are you going to start rehearsing new songs or perfecting your existing ones?

Olly: Thanks so much, De-Graft! I'm still on cloud nine. To be honest, I'm not sure what my plan is yet. I've been thinking about performing a mix of my old and new songs, but I'm also open to trying out some new ones. What do you think? Do you have any suggestions?

De-Graft: Ahaha, you're welcome, Olly! I'm glad you're feeling inspired! I think a mix of old and new songs would be great, it'll give your fans a sense of nostalgia and also showcase your growth as an artist. As for new songs, what kind of vibe are you thinking of going for? Do you have any ideas for a new single or album?

Olly: Ah, yeah, I love that idea! I've been thinking of doing a retro-futuristic vibe for my new songs. You know, something that blends the nostalgia of 80s and 90s synth-pop with some modern electronic elements. As for a new single, I've been working on a track called "Lost in the Moment" that I think could be a great starting point. It's a bit more experimental than my previous work, but I'm really excited about it. What do you think?

I think "Lost in the Moment" sounds like a great direction to take your music in! I love the idea of blending nostalgia with modern elements, it's a really unique sound. Can you tell me more about what inspired this new direction? And what's the vibe of "Lost in the Moment" like? Is it fast-paced and energetic, or more atmospheric and chill?

I'm so glad you're feeling that vibe! To be honest, I've always been drawn to the idea of blending different eras and styles to create something fresh and exciting. I've been listening to a lot of 80s and 90s music lately, and I've been inspired by the way those artists were able to create this sense of nostalgia and longing in their songs. I wanted to capture that same feeling in my own music, but with a modern twist. With "Lost in the Moment", I was thinking of creating a song that's both nostalgic and futuristic at the same time. The vibe is definitely more atmospheric and chill, with a lot of ambient synths and a laid-back beat. It's a song that's meant to be listened to on a rainy night, with the lights dimmed and the world outside feeling a little bit slower.

I love where your head's at with this song! The idea of blending nostalgia with futurism is really intriguing, and I think the atmospheric and chill vibe you're going for could be really effective in capturing that feeling. Have you thought about incorporating any retro synths or samples into the track to give it an extra layer of depth?

I've actually been experimenting with some vintage synth plugins and I think they could add a really cool texture to the track. I was thinking of incorporating some lush, filtered pads to give it a sense of depth and atmosphere, and maybe even some filtered drum sounds to give it a bit of a retro feel. What do you think about incorporating some vinyl crackle or tape hiss to really make it sound like it's been pulled from the past?

I love the idea of incorporating vintage synth plugins! The filtered pads and drum sounds will definitely give the track a unique retro vibe. The vinyl crackle and tape hiss are great suggestions as well - it'll add a nice layer of grit and character to the mix. Maybe we could also experiment with some slowed-down drum samples to give it an even more nostalgic feel. And have you considered adding some warm, analog-style bass to really tie everything together?

That's a great point about the bass! I was thinking we could use a combo of a warm, analog-style synth bass and a slightly distorted, overdriven electric bass to create a rich, full sound. And to take it to the next level, we could even add some subtle, filtered percussion elements, like a filtered tambourine or a heavily processed snare drum, to really make the track pop. What do you think about incorporating some atmospheric pads to add depth and texture to the mix? Maybe some ambient, atmospheric sounds or even some reversed or time-stretched effects to create a sense of space and movement.

I love where you're headed with that! The idea of combining a warm synth bass with an overdriven electric bass is genius, and the addition of filtered percussion elements will definitely give the track a lot of energy. As for the atmospheric pads, I think they would be a great way to add some depth and texture to the mix. I'm particularly intrigued by the idea of using reversed or time-stretched effects to create a sense of space and movement. Have you considered using any specific ambient sounds or instruments, like a solo piano or a softly played acoustic guitar, to add some warmth and intimacy to the track?

Yes, I've actually been experimenting with using a combination of soft piano and ambient guitar textures to add warmth and intimacy to the track. I think the contrast between the bright, pulsing synths and the mellow, atmospheric pads would create a really interesting dynamic. I've also been playing around with using subtle field recordings, like rain or wind sounds, to add some organic texture to the track. What do you think about using a filtered vocal sample or a whispered melody to add some human element to the track?

I love where you're going with this! The idea of using a filtered vocal sample or a whispered melody is genius. It would add a level of vulnerability and emotional depth to the track. Have you considered using a minimalist drum pattern to keep the focus on the textures and melodies, or would you want to introduce a more driving beat to propel the track forward?

I think a minimalist drum pattern could be really effective in highlighting the atmospheric textures and melodies. But at the same time, I can see how a more driving beat could add a sense of tension and release to the track. Maybe we could experiment with layering both approaches to create a sense of contrast and dynamic range. What do you think about incorporating some ambient pads or soundscapes to further enhance the sense of space and atmosphere?

I completely agree, layering the two approaches could create a really interesting dynamic. The ambient pads and soundscapes could add a great depth to the track, and maybe we could also experiment with some filtered or processed drum samples to give the beat a more ethereal quality. Additionally, have you considered incorporating some vocal textures or whispers to add another layer of atmosphere and intimacy to the track?

That's a great idea about the vocal textures! I was thinking we could also try using some reversed or time-stretched vocals to create a sense of space and distance, adding to the overall ethereal feel. And what about incorporating some subtle piano or guitar parts to provide a sense of contrast and human warmth to the track?

I love where this is going! The reversed vocals could add a really interesting layer of depth to the track. I was thinking we could also experiment with using some atmospheric pads or ambient synths to create a sense of atmosphere and mood. And regarding the piano or guitar parts, maybe we could use them sparingly to create these little moments of intimacy and warmth, like a beacon of light in the darkness.

I think that's a great direction to take the song! The reversed vocals could definitely add a unique texture to the track, and the atmospheric pads and ambient synths would help to create a sense of space and depth. I love the idea of using the piano or guitar parts sparingly to create moments of intimacy and warmth - it would be like a little oasis in the midst of all the ambient sounds. What do you think about incorporating some found sounds or field recordings to add to the atmosphere? Maybe some rain sounds or distant thunder to give it a sense of weather and place?

That's a fantastic idea! Found sounds or field recordings can really help to ground the track in a specific time and place, and add a level of realism to the atmosphere. I'm thinking maybe we could also incorporate some sounds from nature, like a babbling brook or a distant forest, to create a sense of tranquility and calm. And if we're going for a more dramatic sound, we could use some sounds like a stormy sea or a howling wind to create a sense of tension and unease. What do you think about using some vocal processing techniques to create a sense of distance or space in the vocals? Maybe some reverb or delay to make it sound like the singer is performing in a massive cathedral or a vast, empty landscape?

I love where this is going! Vocal processing techniques can really add depth and atmosphere to the vocals. And I think it would be really cool to experiment with some unconventional vocal processing techniques, like using a reversed or time-stretched vocal to create an otherworldly or eerie effect. We could also use some creative EQing to make the vocals sound like they're coming from a specific location or object, like a cave or a pipe organ. What about using some audio manipulation software to create a sense of movement or progression in the track, like making the vocals sound like they're drifting or flowing through space?

This could add a really immersive and dynamic feel to the track. I'm thinking we could also use some subtle pitch-shifting to create a sense of tension or unease, like making the vocals seem to be slightly out of tune or wavering. And what about experimenting with different mic placements and recording techniques to capture the vocals in unusual ways, like using a contact mic on a metal surface or recording through a guitar amp?

That's a great idea! By incorporating unusual mic placements and techniques, we could create a sense of unease and tension, adding another layer of depth to the track. We could also try using a combination of close and distant mics to create a sense of space and atmosphere. Additionally, we could experiment with layering multiple vocals to create a sense of disorientation, like a chorus of whispers or murmurs.

This could also be achieved by manipulating the pitch and timbre of the vocals, creating an unsettling and otherworldly quality. We could also incorporate found sounds or field recordings to add to the sense of unease and tension, perhaps using creaking doors, rustling papers, or distant sirens to create an unsettling atmosphere.

Additionally, we could experiment with unconventional instrumentation, such as scraping metal or broken glass, to create an eerie and unsettling sound. We could also incorporate eerie ambient textures, like whispers or soft murmurs, to create a sense of unease and tension.
By layering these unconventional sounds with more traditional instrumentation, we could create a unique and captivating sonic landscape that draws the listener in and refuses to let go.

Through the careful balance of textures and timbres, we can craft a soundscape that is both mesmerizing and emotionally resonant, transporting the listener to a world that is both familiar and unknown.

By manipulating the dynamics and pacing of the music, we can create a sense of tension and release, drawing the listener in and propelling them through a sonic journey that is both personal and universal, evoking emotions that linger long after the music fades away.

Through the strategic use of melody and harmony, we can craft a narrative that unfolds like a story, with each element working together to build a rich tapestry of sound that is at once intimate and expansive, inviting the listener to immerse themselves in the music and become a part of the emotional journey being conveyed.

This narrative can be heightened through the effective use of dynamics, texture, and timbre, allowing the music to ebb and flow like a tide, with moments of quiet introspection giving way to sweeping crescendos that evoke a sense of triumph or release.

The juxtaposition of contrasting moods and emotions can also be achieved through the strategic use of rhythm and tempo, creating a sense of tension and release that draws the listener in and propels the music forward.

By varying the tempo and rhythm, a composer can manipulate the emotional intensity of a piece, crafting a narrative arc that ebb and flows like a sonic wave, culminating in a dramatic climax that leaves the listener breathless and yearning for more.

This mastery of tempo and rhythm is particularly evident in the works of film composers, who must balance the ebb and flow of tension and release to perfectly complement the on-screen action, whether it's a heart-pumping chase scene or a poignant character moment.

For example, the iconic score of "Jaws" by John Williams is a masterclass in using tempo and rhythm to build tension, with a repetitive two-note motif that becomes increasingly frantic as the shark approaches its victims, perfectly capturing the sense of dread and fear that defines the film.

This technique of building tension through music is not unique to "Jaws", however. Many horror movies have used similar methods to great effect, such as the eerie, pulsing theme that accompanies the aliens in "Alien" or the discordant, atonal scores that permeate the works of Italian horror maestro Dario Argento.

For example, Argento's "Suspiria" features a haunting, avant-garde score that perfectly captures the sense of unease and uncertainty that pervades the film, while the creepy, ambient textures of the score for "The Exorcist" add to the film's sense of supernatural menace.

Similarly, the score for "The Shining" by Wendy Carlos and Rachel Elkind creates an eerie and foreboding atmosphere, its use of eerie tones and dissonant harmonies perfectly complementing the film's sense of isolation and madness.

The soundtrack's use of repetitive patterns and minimalist structures adds to the sense of claustrophobia and builds tension as the film's protagonist, Jack Torrance, descends further into madness, making the score a masterclass in atmospheric sound design.

The score's use of eerie silences and discordant notes also creates a sense of unease, mirroring Jack's growing instability as he becomes increasingly obsessed with the hotel's dark past and the supernatural forces that reside within its walls.

As the sun dips below the horizon, the shadows within the hotel's labyrinthine corridors seem to grow longer and darker, like grasping fingers, and Jack's own sanity begins to unravel, his mind consumed by the whispers of the hotel's malevolent inhabitants, who whisper secrets of the past in his ear, tempting him deeper into the abyss.

The air thickens with an unholy presence, heavy with the scent of decay and corruption, as Jack's eyes scan the deserted hallway, his heart racing with every creak of the old wooden floorboards beneath his feet, every flicker of the dim fluorescent lights overhead, every whisper in his ear a cruel reminder that he is not alone, that the hotel's dark history is closing in around him like a shroud.

The shadows seem to writhe and twist around him, like dark, living tendrils, as he pauses at the end of the hall, his breathing ragged and uneven, his eyes darting back and forth, searching for any sign of movement, any hint of the evil that lurks within these crumbling walls, the air growing colder still, heavy with the stench of death and despair, as the silence itself begins to whisper his name, a chilling, mournful whisper that sends shivers down his spine and makes his blood run cold.

And then, he sees it: a faint, flickering light emanating from the doorway to his left, like a candle flame struggling to stay alive, casting eerie shadows on the walls, making the shadows around him seem to writhe and twist even more urgently, as if trying to draw him closer to the source of the light, and the darkness that lies beyond.

His heart racing, he takes a cautious step forward, his eyes fixed on the light, and as he does, the shadows around him seem to grow longer and darker, like grasping fingers, trying to snatch him back, but he presses on, his feet carrying him towards the doorway with an unspoken compulsion, as if the light is beckoning him towards some ancient, forgotten truth, hidden in the depths of the darkness beyond.

As he steps across the threshold, the air thickens around him, heavy with the scent of decay and forgotten memories, and he feels the weight of centuries bearing down upon him, the whispers of the past echoing through the silence, warning him away from the secrets that lie within.

The creaking of the old wooden floorboards beneath his feet seems to amplify the oppressive atmosphere, each step a deliberate defiance of the warnings that hang in the air like a challenge, as he ventures deeper into the abandoned mansion, his eyes adjusting to the dim light that filters through the grimy windows, revealing the remnants of a life long past, the remnants of a family's history etched into every dusty surface, every cobweb-shrouded ornament.

The air is thick with the scent of decay and rot, and he can almost taste the bitterness of forgotten memories as he wanders through the musty halls, his footsteps echoing off the walls like the whispers of the dead, each creaking step a reminder that he is not alone in this haunted place, and yet he presses on, driven by a morbid curiosity to uncover the secrets that lie hidden beneath the layers of dust and neglect, the secrets that have been waiting patiently for someone to stumble upon them, to uncover the truth behind the faded photographs and yellowed letters that litter the floors, the truth that has been buried beneath the silence and the shadows.

As he turns a corner, a faint light flickers to life, casting eerie shadows on the walls, and he feels a shiver run down his spine as he approaches the source: a dusty, old-fashioned lamp, its globe cracked and cloudy with age, yet somehow still managing to emit a faint, otherworldly glow. He reaches out a trembling hand to touch the lamp, and as his fingers make contact, the whispers in the walls seem to grow louder, the air thickening with an almost palpable sense of anticipation, as if the very spirits that haunt this place are urging him forward, deeper into the heart of the mystery, and closer to the truth that lies hidden within the crumbling walls.

The lamp's warm glow seems to seep into his skin, and he feels a strange tingling sensation coursing through his veins, as if the very essence of the whispers is infusing him with a newfound energy and determination. He gazes deeper into the cracked globe, and what appears to be a wispy tendril of smoke begins to coil and uncoil, like a serpent awakening from a centuries-long slumber. Suddenly, the whispers cease, and an oppressive silence falls, as if the spirits are holding their collective breath in anticipation of what is to come. With a sense of foreboding, he slowly raises his gaze to meet the darkness beyond the lamp's feeble light, and it is then that he sees it: a doorway, previously hidden by shadows, now standing revealed, like a portal to the very depths of the unknown.
